comment.author: 21061284@N05
comment._content: Search William Hope. He was one of the premiere spirit photographers of the early Twentieth Century and was considered by believers and supporters to be a true master of the art of producing spirits on ordinary photographic plates. To others, he was a clever trickster and while he had more than his share of detractors, he was often accused of fraud but was never caught at it -- thanks to the controversy that surrounded the main attempt to expose him.

comment.author: 24286668@N00
comment._content:
this is a really cool photo

it's really easy to fake a ghost, and when i first saw this i didn't even think it was a spirit, i just thought "oh, someone accidentally walked behind this couple while they are taking a picture"
back when this picture was taken, like lazysundae said you had to sit still for a long time because the exposure takes so long.  if you had the woman posing as the ghost stand there for about half the exposure and then duck down, you would still get her image but it would be see through and probably slightly blurry, hence a ghostly image
i'm not saying spirits couldn't possibly exist, but it would be very easy to fake this sort of thing, so don't get taken in

comment.author: 34058235@N03
comment._content: The Photo was taken when Photography was a new technology. It was not created on a computer as might be forgotten! It would have been a Dark room experiment needing clever hand shading and  chemical processing of types. The picture would have been amazing in those days. Who wouldn't be tempted to not tell the truth how the picture was created. We do the same today! We love mystery and love to be marvelled. I wish!   Saying all this, the pic tells a little story, it says to me that the couple had lost a greatly loved daughter affecting their lives there-after but the blessing and the message is your loved one is always with you in spirit. Nothing new here then!

comment.author: 23212779@N04
comment._content: As mentioned, this is actually a very easy effect to reproduce.  This is what happens when a long exposure is taken and one of the subjects doesn't stay still, or stay in frame for the entire exposure.  I have played with this effect for fun many times.  Any camera, digital or film, with manual exposure control can produce this effect without the need for photoshop.

comment.author: 78208003@N00
comment._content:
No, ElectricPhotography, you misunderstand Phillycop...

What he means when he says that this wasn't done with Photoshop is that it was done with film and chemicals in a real darkroom. They most probably sandwiched two films and made one print, or else exposed the paper with first one film image and then the next.

Do you know how light sensitive paper is exposed with the image on the film, and then dipped in chemicals to make the picture appear? That's how these ghost photos were done.

DO you know what photographic film is?  Really, no offence, I'm just asking.

If you don't know about that, check it out. And if you ever get a chance to visit or experiment in a real "wet" darkroom, jump at the chance! It's a lot of fun.

comment.realname: Only Peace will Save the World
comment.author: 43123778@N06
comment._content:
I think its been said here why people are still fascinated with these.... they were produced in a completely different time before there was digital imagery.... using double plates and double exposures... 

When they were may peoples eyes and minds were more innocent and took them at, excuse the expression, face value. Today we question everything and we can pick out obvious things such as the light coming from the wrong side.... or the picture opf the "ghost" being a duplicate of another face that has been changed to look "older".

I think there is another fascination also... people have always been and always will be interested in ghosts and the here after. These silly old abvious fakes... are still a connection to our raw fear and beleif systems... They same reason why I religiously what "ghost hunters, ghost lab, Paranormal State, ghost adventures, haunted places...

comment.author: 32130360@N05
comment._content: Cool double exposure.

comment.author: 46751088@N06
comment._content:
I have the glass negatives and the darkroom and  could very easily replicate these pictures,you cannot call them photos because using two together as a sandwich makes a picture,one would be by definition a photograph.
These were done around 1920/30 and quite a few photographers created "artistic pictures" to make people more interested in spending money having their photograph taken.
I have several boxes of unused glass slides and the camera and glass plate holder,but I think it would be a bit of a waste to use them like this.

comment.author: 29139737@N05
comment._content:
I find it really hard to believe that there are real people out there who don't know about double exposures! All of this set of photographs would have been rejected as mistakes when I was studying photography; it often happened that old cameras didn't wind on the film, or the photographer forgot. These days, even film cameras tend to have a failsafe to prevent this, but that doesn't stop the photographer from exposing the paper to two different negatives for half the time each.
The advent of digital photography has completed the move away from a "hands-on" approach to making pictures that was started by processing labs where even the technicians don't touch the film.
